Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Tenant Screening in the Information Age: Implications for Housing Access

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1636961
Katherine Beckett
Anna Reosti
University of Washington

This project investigates the implications of modern background screening procedures for rental housing access and discrimination in the Seattle metropolitan area. In recent years fair housing advocates have raised concerns regarding the potential discriminatory impacts of the shift toward more information-intense screening practices in the private rental housing market, which utilize commercial background search tools to examine applicants' criminal, credit and eviction histories. In response to such concerns, policymakers in some U.S. jurisdictions have recently made calls to regulate how background check information is used to evaluate rental applicants, particularly with respect to criminal records. In contrast to the employment sphere, few scholars to date have investigated whether and how modern background screening procedures in rental housing provide new opportunities for discrimination, or explored how relevant actors on the ground, such as landlords and tenants, understand such issues.

In an effort to remedy those gaps, this dissertation project investigate tenant screening practices from the dual perspectives of rental housing providers and renters who have recently applied for housing. Interviews with renters who have moved within the last six months will identify understudied impediments to housing access, particularly for renters with discrediting background characteristics such as criminal histories, past evictions and/or damaged credit. That knowledge may help fair and affordable housing advocates and social workers in their efforts to improve rental housing access. Interviews with a group of landlords meanwhile will illuminate what motivates those respondents? approaches to screening applicants and help call attention to institutional dynamics that could frustrate legal reform efforts to advance equity in housing access by regulating background screening practices (e.g. fears of financial liability that discourage landlords from renting to applicants with criminal records). These interviews will be conducted in the wake of the recent release of legal guidance from the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) instructing private rental housing providers that policies which categorically exclude applicants with criminal records could run afoul of the Fair Housing Act, and in a metropolitan area where a campaign to "Ban-the-Box", or regulate criminal history screening in housing, is currently underway. As such this research should make a timely contribution to ongoing policy ongoing discussions around how to ensure that tenant screening procedures do not unnecessarily jeopardize fair and equal access to rental housing. This study is also poised to make important contributions to multiple bodies of academic scholarship, including the sociological literatures on the collateral consequences of a criminal record, and socio-legal work on anti-discrimination law in action.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The information age has brought about an unprecedented level of scrutiny with which applicants for rental housing are evaluated. Contemporary landlords are increasingly likely to use commercial background check tools to investigate applicants’ criminal, credit and eviction histories. In addition to impeding housing access for renters with imperfect tenancy, credit or criminal records, these technologies may enhance opportunities for subtle forms of discrimination involving the inconsistent application of background check criteria. This dissertation uses a mixed-methods approach to investigate how rental housing providers screen and select applicants on the basis of discrediting information revealed by background checks. It also evaluates the capacity of recently enacted fair housing policies to combat discriminatory tenant screening practices and broaden housing access for renters with negative background credentials.

During the funding period, forty-six in-depth interviews were transcribed and analyzed that offer insights into contemporary tenant background screening from the divergent perspectives of private rental housing providers and tenants who had recently applied for housing with a criminal record, damaged credit history and/or a past eviction. The interviews were conducted in Seattle, Washington, where some of the nation’s farthest-reaching tenant screening regulations have been recently implemented, including restrictions on criminal background checks by landlords. This local legal environment was leveraged during interviews to explore how the new policies may impact the intended beneficiaries and targets of those regulations.

The second stage of data collection during the funding period involved the design and implementation of an online field experiment that investigated how landlords respond to email inquiries from prospective rental applicants who disclose possessing either a criminal or eviction record, and whether those response patterns are related to the race of applicants (signaled by racially distinctive Black and White names). Before implementing the full experiment, the co-PI used support from this award to acquire training in a computer programming language (Python), that was used to automate many of the experiment’s sampling and sending functions. During the experiment, email inquiries were sent to 1,812 rental housing providers who had posted advertisements for rental vacancies online. During the final phase of the funding period, descriptive quantitative analyses of email response patterns were conducted and the co-PI’s dissertation, “Tenant Screening and Fair Housing in the Information Age,” was filed in June, 2018.

The findings from this research contribute to multiple sociological and socio-legal bodies of academic research, and offer timely insights for housing policymakers interested in improving housing access for renters with stigmatizing background records and/or reducing the discriminatory impacts associated with some forms of tenant screening criteria. The study's findings regarding the housing search experiences of negatively credentialed renters contribute to an emerging body of sociological research investigating how poverty and inequality are reproduced in the private rental housing market. The interview data suggest that for renters with tarnished background records, merely attempting to secure housing in the private market involves a prolonged and arduous search process that can come at a significant costs to one’s physical health, emotional well-being and/or financial security. The study’s interviews with property managers, landlords and other representatives of the private rental industry identify important challenges associated with new policies that aim to broaden rental housing access by transforming the historically difficult to surveil and regulate practices of landlords. Findings from those interviews suggest that private rental housing providers, particularly of the independent or “mom & pop” variety, exercise considerable discretion in screening and selecting tenants that they maintain is vital to their business models. Many respondents also maintained that they are committed to retaining their discretionary powers in the face of new tenant screening regulations.

Finally, findings from the study’s online experiment suggest that in the aggregate, landlords respond to email inquiries from applicants without any discrediting credentials (the control scenario) at significantly higher rates than messages from renters with eviction or criminal conviction records. The experiment found no evidence of racial differences in response rates to rental applicants without discrediting credentials or with criminal records. By contrast, rates of response to email inquiries sent by applicants disclosing a past eviction were differentiated by race, wherein messages mentioning an eviction history were significantly more likely to receive a response when associated with White, rather than Black names. These findings contribute to our understanding of how background screening information can be implicated in subtle forms of housing discrimination, as well as how racial discrimination can compound the significant costs negatively credentialed renters endure during the housing search process.
